abstract.text: A list of rules, together with a context for evaluating them and interpreting results, for use in constructing data-driven logic or fuzzy logic systems.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
object manages a list of rules (
objects). A rule system also offers methods for evaluating its list of rules in a context defined by two features: a
dictionary containing information to be tested by rules, and a set of

representing the conclusions drawn as a result of rule evaluation. You can evaluate facts based on a binary truth state—that is, a fact either is or is not in the set—or on a continuously variable membership grade, representing different levels of veracity, confidence, or strength for use in fuzzy logic.
You construct a rule system by creating

objects and adding them to the system’s list of rules. There are multiple ways to construct rules: for greater reusability, use the methods listed in Creating Data-Driven Rules; or for greater flexibility, use the
method or create a custom subclass of
or
. Then, add rules to the system with the methods listed in Managing a System’s List of Rules below.
To evaluate a system, call the
method. This method processes each rule in the system in the order it appears in the system’s
list. You set this order with the
property of each rule, or with the order in which you add rules to the system. As the system processes each rule, it tests the rule’s
method to determine whether the rule is satisfied in the context of the system. If the rule’s predicate is satisfied, the system executes the rule’s
method and moves the rule to the
list (so the further evaluation of the agenda doesn’t repeatedly trigger the rule’s action).
Rules typically use the system’s
dictionary as input and its set of

as output. (However, more complex systems can include sets of rules whose predicates test facts or whose actions mutate the system’s state.) After evaluating a rule system, you can examine the set of facts it has produced using the methods listed in Drawing Conclusions from Facts below. You can then use the presence of a fact in the set, the value of its membership grade, or the combined membership grades of a group of facts to influence the behaviors in your game.
For more information about rules and rule systems, read
in

abstract.text: A definition of logical conditions for constraining a search for a fetch or for in-memory filtering.
Architect and organize your game logic. Incorporate common gameplay behaviors such as random number generation, artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and agent behavior.
A rule for use in a rule system that uses a Foundation
object to evaluate itself.
A rule to be used in the context of a rule system, with a predicate to be tested and an action to be executed when the test succeeds.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the rule has been satisfied in the context of the specified rule system.
Creates a rule whose predicate is evaluated and action is executed through the specified blocks.
Performs actions that should result when the rule is satisfied in the context of the specified rule system.
The importance of the rule relative to others in a rule system’s agenda.
A list of rules, together with a context for evaluating them and interpreting results, for use in constructing data-driven logic or fuzzy logic systems.
Adds the specified rule to the system.
Adds the specified list of rules to the system.
The list of rules to be considered when evaluating the system.
Adds the specified fact to the fact set with a membership grade of 1.0, and reevaluates the rules in the system’s agenda.
Increases the membership grade of the specified fact by the specified amount, adding it to the fact set if necessary, and reevaluates the rules in the system’s agenda.
Evaluates the rule system, executing the list of rules in its agenda.
The list of rules whose actions have been performed during evaluation of the system.
The list of facts claimed by the rule system.
Returns the membership grade of the specified fact.
Initializes a new, empty rule system.
Returns the highest membership grade among the specified facts.
Returns the lowest membership grade among the specified facts.
Removes all rules from the system.
Returns the rule system to its original agenda and clears all facts.
Removes the specified fact from the fact set, and reevaluates the rules in the system’s agenda.
Reduces the membership grade of the specified fact by the specified amount, removing it from the fact set if necessary, and reevaluates the rules in the system’s agenda.
The list of rules to be executed when evaluating the system.
A dictionary of state information to be evaluated by the system’s rules.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
